<![CDATA[Value innovation, not #technology innovation, is what launches commercially compelling new #markets!
With limited resources at hand, companies need to stay smart and efficient when it comes to investing in innovation.
This is a challenging time for many companies. On the one hand, supply chain disruption, labour shortage, raw material and energy price hikes are driving up business costs. On the other, demand is slack due to consumersâ€™ reduced purchasing power and an uncertain global economic outlook. Together these conditions squeeze companiesâ€™ profits and cast a shadow on their #growth prospects. In this time of difficulty, executives around the world find it more urgent than ever to sharpen their organisationsâ€™ innovation #strategy to create new markets for growth.
Economics has long taught us that R&D and technology advances, as measured by R&D spending and a number of patents, are the central drivers of innovation and growth. But market creation for growth is not inevitably about technological innovation.
With limited resources at hand, companies need to stay smart and efficient when it comes to investing in innovation. item.title: Post 847
item.description:
<![CDATA[The digital age has challenged organizations to adapt and evolve their business practices. Many companies have invested heavily in digital transformation, but despite the projected $6.8 trillion spent by 2023, they often fail to see the expected return on investment. This is due to a lack of understanding of the steps required for a successful transformation.
Buying technology and investing in the latest tech tools is not enough to drive change. It's crucial to have the right processes, culture, and talent in place to fully utilize these tools. The failure to invest in skills development is a significant contributor to the lack of productivity gains from new technologies like AI. Convincing experienced employees and senior managers to embrace new tech tools can also be a challenge for many organizations.
Many companies have fallen into the trap of thinking that technology alone will drive change. But the reality is, without the right processes, culture, and talent in place, even the best technology will fail to deliver results.
#DigitalTransformation #BusinessTransformation #Employees #ReSkilling #Training #Technology #Transformation #Business #Growth #Success #AI]]>

item.title: Post 843
item.description:
<![CDATA[This year, executives face new challenges and opportunities for growth, including navigating the impact of trends like inflation, scarce talent, and global supply constraints. To drive business resilience, growth, and profits, organizations need to couple radical efficiency with innovation and invest shrewdly in digital.
Smart budget trade-offs, savvy talent strategies, and optimal digital investments will be key to success this year, with organizations focusing on driving margin improvement, generating cash, increasing the productivity of people and assets, and capitalizing on new growth opportunities with fewer resources.
But to succeed, executives must tackle three variables that threaten to weigh down growth and profits in 2023: higher interest rates, lack of available talent, and lagging digital transformation. Higher funding costs reduce ROI and funding is harder to get and justify as investors prioritize investments that generate short-term profitability and cash flow over those that drive future growth. Critical talent, especially those with digital skills, remains expensive and in short supply, despite the slew of layoffs in the tech sector. Boards and CEOs now expect to see top or bottom-line benefits from digital investments, but many CIOs still struggle to demonstrate the business value of IT.
To differentiate performance in 2023, executives need to manage resources and spend strategically, be agile in securing digital talent, and accelerate key digital and technology initiatives. The recession playbook of nine winning actions that Gartner recommended in mid-2022 holds true, with a focus on driving digital transformation success.
#digitaltransformation #innovativesolutions #strategy #strategicthinking #businessgrowth #resilience #productivity #talentretention #digitalstrategy #digitalinvestment #budgetmanagement #CFOs #CIOs #executives #businesssuccess #supplychainconstraints #cashgeneration #growthopportunities #digitaltalent #investmentpriorities #ROI #businessvalue #differentiation #performancesuccess #enterprisestrategy

item.title: Post 741
item.description:
<![CDATA[Industry 4.0 has transformed the way new products are designed and engineered. The use of sensors, wearables, analytics, and Machine Learning (ML), as well as advanced manufacturing, Augmented Reality/Virtual Reality (AR/VR), advanced computer numerical control, and robotics have improved products in multiple ways. Industries have moved from rapid prototyping and testing to adding connectivity features to unconnected products along with innovative features.
Organisations are now moving towards monetising the data that they capture via smart products and bundle services in addition to physical assets. Digital signals from consumer interactions with connected assets on the field or from the assets themselves can enable better services and improve warranty claims, visibility into usage patterns, and overall revenue streams.
To utilise these opportunities arising from Industry 4.0, it is necessary to shift from traditional to novel business models.
Smart products present a spectrum of new business model innovations to capture value. For example, there has been a recent shift from traditional ownership models (where customer benefits from the product delivered) to a Product-as-a-Service model (PaaS), where the manufacturer retains ownership and takes full responsibility for the costs of product operation, maintenance, and service in return for a fixed fee. This enables customers to pay as they go. Here, the value from the improvement in product performance, reduction in the overall cost of production, and higher service efficiency are captured by the manufacturer.
Source: Deloitte
#business #manufacturing #data #digital #analytics #businessmodels #businessmodel #innovation #digitaltransformation

item.title: Post 739

<![CDATA[Value innovation, not #technology innovation, is what launches commercially compelling new #markets!
With limited resources at hand, companies need to stay smart and efficient when it comes to investing in innovation.
This is a challenging time for many companies. On the one hand, supply chain disruption, labour shortage, raw material and energy price hikes are driving up business costs. On the other, demand is slack due to consumersâ€™ reduced purchasing power and an uncertain global economic outlook. Together these conditions squeeze companiesâ€™ profits and cast a shadow on their #growth prospects. In this time of difficulty, executives around the world find it more urgent than ever to sharpen their organisationsâ€™ innovation #strategy to create new markets for growth.
Economics has long taught us that R&D and technology advances, as measured by R&D spending and numbers of patents, are the central drivers of innovation and growth. But market creation for growth is not inevitably about technological innovation.
With limited resources at hand, companies need to stay smart and efficient when it comes to investing in innovation. If technologies are involved, they should enable and facilitate the delivery of key buyer value elements, instead of making products or services too futuristic, esoteric or complicated for customers to adopt.

item.title: Post 732
item.description:
<![CDATA[This year, executives face new challenges and opportunities for growth, including navigating the impact of trends like inflation, scarce talent, and global supply constraints. To drive business resilience, growth, and profits, organizations need to couple radical efficiency with innovation and invest shrewdly in digital.
Smart budget trade-offs, savvy talent strategies, and optimal digital investments will be key to success this year, with organizations focusing on driving margin improvement, generating cash, increasing the productivity of people and assets, and capitalizing on new growth opportunities with fewer resources.
But to succeed, executives must tackle three variables that threaten to weigh down growth and profits in 2023: higher interest rates, lack of available talent, and lagging digital transformation. Higher funding costs reduce ROI and funding is harder to get and justify as investors prioritize investments that generate short-term profitability and cash flow over those that drive future growth. Critical talent, especially those with digital skills, remains expensive and in short supply, despite the slew of layoffs in the tech sector. Boards and CEOs now expect to see top or bottom-line benefits from digital investments, but many CIOs still struggle to demonstrate the business value of IT.
To differentiate performance in 2023, executives need to manage resources and spend strategically, be agile in securing digital talent, and accelerate key digital and technology initiatives. The recession playbook of nine winning actions that Gartner recommended in mid-2022 holds true, with a focus on driving digital transformation success.

For manufacturing plants, data has become a valuable resource. item.title: Post 713
item.description:
<![CDATA[How Carbon Offset Technologies Can Help?
The most common way to reduce CO2 emissions is through carbon offset technologies, namely avoided emissions and carbon removal. Though they serve a similar purpose, these two methods are fundamentally different.
One metric ton of CO2 is reduced or avoided for every metric ton of CO2 emitted in avoided emissions. This still leads to a positive increase in emissions overall.
On the other hand, carbon removal technologies completely remove and store one metric ton of CO2 for every metric ton of CO2 emitted.
Carbon removal technologies have a distinct advantage over the avoided emissions. For this reason, they could be the future of CO2 emissions reduction. They are divided into short-term and long-term methods based on the CO2 emissions they can remove and store.
Short-term methods include soil carbon sequestration, reforestation, biochar, wooden buildings, and more. Direct Air Capture with Carbon Storage (DACCS), Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage (BECCS) and enhanced weathering are considered long-term methods.
A great visual by Visual Capitalist: http://ow.ly/k8Cr50IwsV1

<![CDATA[When you think of digital twins, you may be picturing a new product, a fantastic technology or even a business model.
But there are also many other scenarios where digital twins are used as a way to measure and improve the performance of an existing product.
A digital twin is a virtual representation that serves as the real-time digital counterpart of a physical object or process. The virtual twin is disrupting the entire product lifecycle management (PLM), from design to manufacturing to service and operations. The logic behind this is that any time there is a link between physical objects and processes, the potential for performance improvement exists.
Digital twins can provide enterprises with cost benefits by â€¢ reducing machine downtime, â€¢ decreasing inventory holding costs, â€¢ improving efficiency, â€¢ increasing quality, â€¢ empowering customers, â€¢ saving space, â€¢ improving productivity, â€¢ saving energy, â€¢ improving process automation, â€¢ expanding market reach by providing more value for customers at lower costs than traditional solutions such as paper-based records which consume up to 80% of all energy produced during their production cycle; â€¢ lowering purchase price tags by enabling smaller organizations to deal primarily with small volumes.

A digital roadmap is a plan that outlines the steps and actions your organization needs to take to achieve its digital goals. It should align with your overall business strategy and take into account the current state of your organization's digital capabilities, as well as the external factors that may impact your progress.
A strategic approach is crucial when creating a digital roadmap. This means identifying your organization's digital goals and objectives and aligning them with your overall business strategy. It's also important to take into account the current state of your organization's digital capabilities and identify any gaps that need to be addressed.
To create a digital roadmap, it's also important to involve internal stakeholders, including key decision-makers, IT, and other departments. This will help ensure buy-in and support for the roadmap, and also provide valuable insights into the current state of your organization's digital capabilities.
There are several frameworks available to help organizations create a digital roadmap. One popular framework is the SOSTAC model, which stands for Situation, Objectives, Strategy, Tactics, Actions, and Control.
When creating a digital roadmap, it's also important to consider best-case scenarios and how to achieve them. This could include identifying potential partnerships or collaborations that could help accelerate your progress or identifying the latest technologies that could help drive innovation and competitiveness.
It's important to note that a digital roadmap is not a one-time project, but rather an ongoing process that should be reviewed and updated regularly. This will help ensure that it stays aligned with your organization's goals and objectives, and takes into account any external factors that may impact your progress. Also, it's important to communicate the digital roadmap to all stakeholders, including employees, partners, and customers. This will help ensure buy-in and support for the roadmap, and also provide valuable insights into the current state of your organization's digital capabilities.
By taking a strategic approach, involving key stakeholders, and utilizing frameworks such as SOSTAC or Agile methodology, organizations can create a roadmap that aligns with their overall business strategy and takes into account the current state of their digital capabilities.

item.title: Post 704
item.description:
<![CDATA[By 2020, 40 years after the development of the first commercial machines, analysis of the AM sector showed it had grown to a â‚¬13.4 billion industry with a 22 percent annual growth rate. The sector remains extremely dynamic, with more than 200 players competing to develop new hardware, software, and materials.
Rapid innovation is driving major improvements in the performance of AM technologies. The newest generations of machines are overcoming many of the perceived limitations of their predecessors, such as by allowing the production of overhanging parts without the need for elaborate printed support structures, or creating stronger parts by controlling the alignment of fiber reinforcements using magnetic fields. The range of materials available for AM systems continues to expand, including high-strength aluminum alloys and medical-grade polymers.
AM systems are getting faster, too. Recent systems based on selective laser sintering (SLS), for example, use as many as one million laser diodes to accelerate the production of parts. And improvements to software and postprocessing technologies are further streamlining the end-to-end journey from concept to finished component. AM technologies pair very well with generative-design systems, which use AI techniques to define and optimize the geometry of parts.
In many sectors, AM has become widely accepted as the fastest and most cost-effective way to produce functional prototypes during product development and testing. AM technologies are also being applied in a growing range of â€œindirectâ€ applications, including tooling, spare parts, and fixtures for conventional manufacturing machines.
Excellent overview of the AM by McKinsey & Company: http://ow.ly/aimm50Imchw

item.title: Post 683
item.description:
<![CDATA[Creating a clear path to Industry 4.0 transformation
Based on its experience with industrial clients, MIT Sloan School of Management has developed a strategy to avoid falling into the trap of purchasing technology that is underutilised or fails to deliver the desired business outcomes. It is recommended for a more gradual transition process that incorporates systems thinking and addresses cultural norms.
This will translate lofty Industry 4.0 visions into actionable strategies and next steps to improve internal processes. The following are important steps:
The initial stages of transformation will be driven by ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€. Manufacturers frequently install networks of hundreds of sensors and then return to solve a specific problem. Problems are not solved by technology. In fact, technology has the potential to exacerbate problems by increasing data overload and eroding employees' trust in the new system.
Instead of launching a full-scale network with hundreds of sensors, a more cautious approach that focuses on a specific problem and uses Industry 4.0 capabilities to solve it is recommended. Engaging employees to identify critical stress points in their jobs, as well as evaluating processes to identify opportunities for improvement and value creation, is critical for larger transformation.
Begin by "ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´" ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—ºğ—¶ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´. Knowing where to establish a feedback loop is critical to the business value of Industry 4.0, but the question is where to begin. According to this roadmap, the best way to get started with Big Data is to first understand what it is and what it can do for your organisation, and then work with a multidisciplinary team to develop Proof of Concepts. These initial Proof of Concepts are critical for your company's data-driven transformation and should be shared with all employees.
Knowledgent's infographic below depicts five levels of Big Data maturity within an organisation. The first level is referred to as the Infancy phase, and it is the stage at which one begins to understand Big Data and develop Proof of Concepts.
The second level they identified is the technical adoption phase, in which the company prepares to implement various Big Data technologies. These technologies, whether on-premises or in the cloud, will allow a company to develop new Proof of Concepts / products or Big Data services more quickly and effectively.
An organisation enters level 3 of the Big Data maturity index once the IT department is capable of working with Big Data technologies and the business understands what Big Data can do for them. More in-depth analysis of structured and unstructured data available within the company will result in more insights and better decision-making.
Level 4 is where Big Data analytics has become an integral part of the company's culture and has resulted in integrated predictive insights into business operations. This is the final level before becoming a fully data-driven organisation that operates as a "data service provider." Companies that have achieved level 5 of the Big Data maturity index have integrated Big Data analytics at all levels of their organisation, are truly data-driven, and can be considered 'data companies' regardless of the product or service they provide. Based on their Big Data insights, they will significantly outperform their competitors.

item.title: Post 661
item.description:
<![CDATA[If you are a CEO or a CTO of a company that relies on digital technology, you might be familiar with the challenges of keeping up with the changing demands of your customers and the market. You might also be experiencing the symptoms of what is called the "Monolith Syndrome", a condition where your technology team cannot deliver the features and performance that your business needs.
The "Monolith Syndrome" is caused by having a single codebase and a single database that was developed years ago and has not evolved much since. This makes it hard to scale, test, deploy and maintain your application. It also creates bottlenecks, outages and bugs that frustrate your customers and employees.
The solution to the "Monolith Syndrome" is to undergo a digital transformation, where you refactor your monolith into microservices. Microservices are small, independent and loosely coupled units of functionality that communicate through APIs. They allow you to develop, deploy and scale your application faster, easier and more reliably.

item.description:
<![CDATA[Digitization and prosperity: the economic growth of nations is linked to one factor: adoption of information and communications technology.
The effect of digitization on a countryâ€™s economy is highly visible. In the 150 countries covered by the study of Booz & Company. an increase in digitization of 10 percentage points triggered a 0.50 to 0.62 percent gain in per capita GDP.
The more advanced the country, the greater the impact of digitization appears to be, which establishes a virtuous feedback cycle: A country reinforces and accelerates its own progress as it moves along the line.
Digitization also has a significant impact on job creation: A 10 percent increase in digitization reduces a nationâ€™s unemployment rate by 0.84 percent. This is an especially critical finding for emerging markets, which will need to create hundreds of millions of jobs in the coming decade to ensure that a booming population of young people can contribute to their national economy.
Finally, a 10-point increase in digitization has, on average, led to a six-point increase in the countryâ€™s score on the INSEAD Global Innovation Index, which ranks countries according to innovation potential. In other words, as a country progresses in its digitization development, it appears to become more innovative.]]>

item.title: Post 657
item.description:
<![CDATA[Industry 4.0 has transformed the way new products are designed and engineered. The use of sensors, wearables, analytics, and Machine Learning (ML), as well as advanced manufacturing, Augmented Reality/Virtual Reality (AR/VR), advanced computer numerical control, and robotics have improved products in multiple ways. Industries have moved from rapid prototyping and testing to adding connectivity features to unconnected products along with innovative features.
Organisations are now moving towards monetising the data that they capture via smart products and bundle services in addition to physical assets. Digital signals from consumer interactions with connected assets on the field or from the assets themselves can enable better services and improve warranty claims, visibility into usage patterns, and overall revenue streams.
To utilise these opportunities arising from Industry 4.0, it is necessary to shift from traditional to novel business models.
Smart products present a spectrum of new business model innovations to capture value. For example, there has been a recent shift from traditional ownership models (where the customer benefits from the product delivered) to a Product-as-a-Service model (PaaS), where the manufacturer retains ownership and takes full responsibility for the costs of product operation, maintenance, and service in return for a fixed fee. This enables customers to pay as they go. Here, the value from the improvement in product performance, reduction in the overall cost of production, and higher service efficiency are captured by the manufacturer.
Source: Deloitte
#business #manufacturing #data #digital #analytics #businessmodel #innovation #digitaltransformation #industry40 #businesstransformation #smartfactory ]]>

<![CDATA[Predictive maintenance, also known as condition-based maintenance, is a strategy that involves monitoring equipment during regular operations to predict potential failures and prevent downtime.
By tracking changes in vibration frequency and amplitude, a predictive maintenance program can enable decision-making to maximize the cost-benefit of allowing a non-essential and easily replaced part to fail, vs. maximizing the run time of a process-critical part.
Many modern vibration sensors include AI/ML technology that interprets the data to help the team make smarter decisions. Before implementing a predictive maintenance program, it's important to consider â€¢ how the new sensor data will integrate with existing tech and operating processes, â€¢ the human-based actions that will be driven by the new data, and â€¢ the automated processes that will be driven across the tech stack to maximize value through integration with purchasing, planning, and maintenance management systems.

item.title: Post 641
item.description:
<![CDATA[These are two different ways of approaching the market and creating value for customers.
The red-ocean strategy is based on the assumption that the market is fixed and defined by existing industry structures. In this scenario, companies compete fiercely for a limited share of the market. They try to gain an edge over their rivals by improving their products or services, lowering their costs, or increasing their marketing efforts. However, this often leads to a tight competition where profits are reduced and growth is limited. The red-ocean strategy is a zero-sum game where one company's gain is another company's loss.
Blue-ocean strategy is based on the idea that the market is fluid and can be shaped by innovative actions. In this scenario, companies create new demand and new markets by offering something unique and valuable to customers. They do not follow the existing rules of the industry but rather redefine them or create new ones. They focus on creating value innovation, which means delivering superior value to customers while reducing costs. The blue-ocean strategy is a positive-sum game where everyone can benefit from the creation of new wealth.
Blue oceans are the untapped opportunities that lie beyond the current boundaries of the industry. They are the result of breaking away from the competition and creating new values for customers. Blue oceans are characterized by:
- Expanding the value proposition of the industry - Aligning with external trends and forces - Enhancing the price-performance trade-off of the industry - Serving a broader range of customers - Making competitors irrelevant - Having a distinctive position in the market
#blueoceanstrategy #redoceanstrategy #valueinnovation #businessstrategy #digitaltransformation #marketing]]>

<![CDATA[How can you ensure that your organization is ready and capable of implementing change effectively?
Business transformation is not just about changing processes, systems or structures. It is also about changing mindsets, behaviours and culture. A process point of view is a way of thinking that focuses on how work gets done in an organization, rather than on who does it or what tools are used. It involves identifying, analyzing, designing, and managing the core processes that deliver value to customers and stakeholders.
A process point of view can help you:
â€¢ Align your processes with your vision, mission, and strategy â€¢ Identify and eliminate waste, inefficiencies, and redundancies â€¢ Improve customer satisfaction and loyalty â€¢ Enhance collaboration and communication across functions and departments â€¢ Foster a culture of continuous improvement and innovation â€¢ Increase agility and adaptability to changing market conditions
If organizations adopt a process point of view, they can transform from a collection of silos to a network of interrelated and interdependent processes that work together to achieve a common purpose. Organizations can also leverage the power of process modelling, simulation, automation, and optimization to streamline their workflows and optimize their performance.

Manufacturers face two common challenges: 1. traditional siloed architectures that don't support tackling high-value use cases and 2. handling vast amounts of data that often exceed existing specs.
To overcome these limitations, manufacturing CIOs are investing in data lakes to collect all manufacturing data into one repository.
However, the approach falls short of providing structured information and tools to enhance end-to-end operations.
The concept of digital twins is gaining attention from manufacturing leaders because it can contextualize data from multiple sources and provide a 'one-stop-shop' for various use cases, such as simulation and predictive/adaptive intelligence at scale.

item.title: Post 612
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is RPA?
RPA is a form of business process automation where software robots are used to carry out repetitive and rules-based tasks. RPA can be used to automate a wide range of tasks, including data entry, data mining, and process monitoring.
RPA is becoming increasingly popular as businesses look for ways to automate low-value tasks and free up employees to focus on more strategic work. RPA software is typically easy to use and can be deployed quickly, making it a cost-effective solution for many organizations.
When considering RPA, it is important to understand the capabilities of the software and how it can be used to benefit your business. This introduction will provide an overview of RPA, its key features, and common use cases.
What are the key features of RPA?
RPA software typically includes the following features:
- A user interface that allows users to configure the software to carry out specific tasks - A set of tools for developing and testing automation scripts - The ability to integrate with existing business applications - A library of pre-built automation scripts
What are the benefits of RPA?
RPA can provide a number of benefits for businesses, including:
- Increased efficiency: RPA can be used to automate tasks that are currently being carried out manually, such as data entry and process monitoring. This can help to improve efficiency and free up employees to focus on other tasks.
- Reduced costs: RPA can help to reduce the cost of business processes by eliminating the need for manual labor.
- Improved compliance: RPA can be used to automate compliance-related tasks, such as auditing and report generation. This can help to improve an organization's compliance posture.
- Greater agility: RPA can help businesses to quickly adapt to changes in business processes. For example, if a new regulation is introduced, RPA can be used to automatically update the relevant business processes.
What are the common use cases for RPA?
RPA can be used to automate a wide range of tasks. Some common use cases for RPA include:
- Data entry: RPA can be used to automatically populate data fields in business applications.
- Data mining: RPA can be used to extract data from multiple sources and compile it into a single format.
- Process monitoring: RPA can be used to monitor business processes and identify areas of improvement.
- Report generation: RPA can be used to generate reports based on data from multiple sources.
Other possible ideas are given on the picture.

<![CDATA[ğŸ¯ Business Innovation is About New Value, Not New Things.
Innovation is relevant only if it creates value for customers â€” and therefore for the firm. Thus creating â€œnew thingsâ€ is neither necessary nor sufficient for business innovation. Customers are the ones who decide the worth of an innovation by voting with their wallets. It makes no difference how innovative a company thinks it is. What matters is whether customers will pay.
ğŸ’¡ Successful business innovation requires the careful consideration of all aspects of a business. A great product with a lousy distribution channel will fail just as spectacularly as a terrific new technology that lacks a valuable end-user application. Thus, when innovating, a company must consider all dimensions of its business system.
Based on discussions with managers leading innovation efforts at various large companies and a comprehensive survey of the academic literature on the topic, the authors of the study, validated and applied a new framework called the â€œinnovation radar.â€ This tool presents and relates all of the dimensions through which a firm can look for opportunities to innovate.
ğŸ¯ Much like a map, the innovation radar consists of four key dimensions that serve as business anchors: (1) the offerings a company creates, (2) the customers it serves, (3) the processes it employs and (4) the points of presence it uses to take its offerings to market. Between these four anchors, eight other dimensions of the business system are embedded that can serve as avenues of pursuit. Thus, the innovation radar contains a total of 12 key dimensions:
1. Offering 2. Platform 3. Solutions 4. Customers 5. Customer Experience 6. Value Capture 7. Process 8. Organization 9. Supply Chain 10. Presence 11. Networking 12. Brand

Measure what matters!
Only 4% of organizations have no digital initiative at all, which signals a shift from digital as an option to digital as a mainstream platform. And yet, Gartner survey found that almost half of CEOs had no metrics for digital business transformation. Boards of directors typically look for benefits, costs and risks of following a digital transformation plan â€” or of not doing anything at all.
When it comes to creating digital KPIs, keep it simple. "Choose KPIs that you can measure easily. Donâ€™t try to build a KPI hierarchy. Select just 5 to 9 metrics to track, report and act on. The value of a metric lies in its ability to influence business decision making.â€ KPIs need to be industry-specific and then organization-specific to be meaningful and useful. To create a digital KPI, ask these five key questions:
1. What is being measured? An example might be the percentage of customer interactions that are virtual/digital. 2. Where are we today? 3. What is our target goal? 4. What is our desired business outcome/benefit (for example, 50% better customer outcomes and 20% lower cost)? 5. What is our balance point?
A â€œbalance pointâ€ describes the reasons why an enterprise shouldnâ€™t overdigitalize.

Do you want to create a company business model that can thrive in the future? If so, you need to learn how to design and innovate your business model based on different scenarios.
In todayâ€™s dynamic and uncertain environment, business models need to be constantly updated and adapted to changing conditions. To design effective business models for the future, we need to enhance our knowledge of the external factors that influence them. These include market forces, industry forces, key trends, and macroeconomic forces.
However, predicting the future is not easy, as there are many complexities, uncertainties, and potential disruptions that may affect the business environment. Therefore, we need to develop multiple scenarios based on different assumptions about how these factors will evolve. These scenarios will help us identify the possible opportunities and challenges for our business models and create various options or prototypes to test and evaluate. Business model scenarios also play a critical role in forecasting, as they help us visualize and communicate the future more clearly. Depending on our own criteria (e.g., an acceptable level of risk, growth potential sought, etc.), we can then select the most suitable option for our business model innovation (BMI).
BMI is a key driver of firm performance and competitiveness. According to a recent study by the OECD, firms that introduced product or business process innovations between 2016 and 2018 had higher productivity growth than non-innovators. Another study found that the business model accounts for 5.1% of a firmâ€™s return on investment, after controlling for other factors. Moreover, BMI can help firms cope with environmental and social challenges, such as climate change, resource scarcity, and social inclusion. Therefore, understanding and managing BMI processes is essential for firms to succeed in the long term.

<![CDATA[Just yesterday, I discussed the change process with the client and we had a discussion which lead to discovering the full spectrum of the emotions they are dealing with during the digital transformation implementations. This also reminded me on the post by Jeroen Kraaijenbrink few days back.
Change is not a quick or easy thing. It takes time and can hurt. But you can cope better if you know what to expect and how to react. Also,c hange is not just a rational choice or a simple action. Change means giving up something and feeling many emotions. You canâ€™t skip these emotions, but you can learn from them.
Change is like a roller coaster. It has ups and downs, but it follows a pattern.Â Â You start with loss and denial. You feel shocked, angry, and anxious. Then you enter a transition period. You realize that change is real and unavoidable. You feel confused, frustrated, and depressed. At the end, you reach acceptance and hope. You start to see the benefits of change and get creative. You feel impatient, optimistic, and energized.
If you know what to expect and how to act, you can make change work for you and your employees.

item.title: Post 577
item.description:
<![CDATA[Based on my previous post about Red-Ocean/Blue-Ocean strategies it is also interesting to see how Blue-Ocean compares to Porter's Five Forces model.
Porterâ€™s Five Forces model focuses on developing a strategic framework that starts with analyzing the external environment. It provides insight into the intensity of competition, potential profitability, and attractiveness of an industry by focusing on the industry and market. However, it is limited to existing value propositions and profit opportunities.
On the other hand, the Blue Ocean Strategy is an approach to innovate value and create new market space by tapping into unsatisfied consumer demand and finding uncontested market space. As a result, competition becomes irrelevant because the rules of the game are yet to be set.
It's important to point out that Porterâ€™s Five Forces model is a valuable tool for analyzing existing markets while the Blue Ocean Strategy is a powerful tool for creating new markets.
#strategy #strategyexecution #blueoceanstrategy #blueocean #business #businessadvisory #transformation #businesstransformation #newproducts #newservices ]]>

item.description:
<![CDATA[In 2019, the global economy consumed more than 100 billion tons of resourcesâ€”primarily virgin metal ores, fossil fuels, biomass and mineralsâ€”and only 8.6% of this was cycled back into use.
Automakers around the world are looking for ways to increase circularity in order to reduce waste and Scope 3 emissions, strengthen supply chain resilience, and generate new value as they transition to a low-carbon future. Many automakers have committed to programs to enhance circularity, including using more recycled materials and remanufactured components in production, and better managing the reclamation of materials from vehicles at the end of their useful lives.
In the mobility sector, circularity means more than just recycling the parts from scrap vehicles. Full circularity includes adhering to principles of circular design (for example, reducing the need for materials, cutting waste, and increasing the potential for end-of-life reuse and recycling), increasing the amount of recycled content in production, and deploying business models that improve vehicle utilizationâ€”meaning, they are used more hours of the day. Because mobility represents a significant share of global emissions (about 30%), any comprehensive approach to mitigating climate change must substantially reshape the ways that vehicles are produced, used, and recycled. The sector is responsible for about 10% of the worldâ€™s material footprint, so circularity is also key to decoupling the need for transportation from material consumption.
Source: Bain & Company]]>

item.title: Post 552
item.description:
<![CDATA[Companies often assume that if they embrace digital technology in any way, theyâ€™re digitally transforming their business. As a result, they often make only ad hoc changes and investments in the digital arena, with ineffectual results. The challenge, to which most companies have yet to rise, is figuring out how to fully capture the different kinds of value that these technologies offer. Developing a strategy for digital transformation that fully leverages this value is also not easy. Without a comprehensive assessment of what digital technologies can offer, firms tend to assume that any application of modern digital technologies will lead to a digital transformation.
Defined by Harvard Business Review there are four distinct tiers of digital transformation, each of which meets different strategic objectives and allows companies to maximize the value they capture from digital technologies:
1. Tier One: Operational efficiencies 2. Tier Two: Advanced operational efficiencies 3. Tier Three: Data-driven services from value chains 4. Tier Four: Data-driven services from digital platforms
To think properly about these four tiers of transformation, the first step is to recognize that modern digital technologies have two notable value drivers: data in its new expansive role, and emergent digital ecosystems.
Data used to be episodic (generated by discrete events such as the shipment of a component from a supplier), but increasingly it is becoming interactive (generated continuously by sensors and the IoT to track information). Two main kinds of digital ecosystems have emerged, neither of which existed before modern advances in data and digital connectivity. One kind is the production ecosystem, which encompasses digital linkages within value chains. By linking sensor and IoT data from cars to spare-part suppliers, warehouses, and service dealers, for example, car companies can offer predictive maintenance services. The other kind is the consumption ecosystem, which involves networks outside of a firmâ€™s value chain.
#digitaltransformation #businesstransformation #business #innovation #growth #operations

Whether this moment leads to a turn in the business cycle or to a continuation of recent inflationary trends, it is a time when companies can make the kind of pivot that strengthens their growth trajectory for the next several years. A research done by McKinsey & Company indicates that the moves companies make now could account for half of the difference in total shareholder returns (TSR) between leading and lagging companies over the next business cycle. Companies head into this uncertainty with different degrees of readiness and health. Most fall into one of four camps:
1. Some are poised to thrive. They enjoy relatively inelastic demand for high-margin products, find it relatively easy to attract and retain talent, and have blessedly simple supply chains. Financially, they have strong balance sheets, low leverage, and ample cash. For them, the strategic options are multiplying.
2. Other companies are more constrained. Their varied challenges include greater susceptibility to a slowing economy, recent loss of market share to new entrants, thinner margins now being inflated away, labour challenges, and more complicated supply chains. As a result, their balance sheets can be more challenged. These companies can resolve to reform.
3. A third group faces a fight to survive. Their balance sheets are loaded with debt, their cash reserves are dwindling, and some are highly exposed to geopolitical disruption, particularly from Russiaâ€™s war in Ukraine.
4. Finally, a fourth group of mostly newer entrants has, to date, successfully focused on #growth and #market share rather than profitability; however, if they do not pivot to profit, more funding will probably be harder to find.

item.title: Post 542
item.description:
<![CDATA[In a world where machines are becoming increasingly sophisticated, it's no surprise that some companies are offering them as a service.
Instead of buying a machine outright, you can now pay a monthly fee to use one. The term â€œmachine as a serviceâ€ (MaaS) is used to describe the outsourcing of the management and maintenance of machinery to a specialist service provider. The service provider is responsible for ensuring that the machinery is kept in good working order and is available to the customer on an as-needed basis.
MaaS arrangements are becoming increasingly popular as businesses seek to reduce their costs and free up their own staff to focus on their core activities. There are a number of advantages to using a MaaS provider, including access to expertise and specialist equipment, lower costs, and increased flexibility. First, it can be cheaper than buying a machine outright, since you're only paying for the use of the machine, not the entire purchase price. Second, it can be more convenient, since the company takes care of maintenance and repairs.
MaaS providers typically offer a range of services, from simple repair and maintenance services to more comprehensive support packages that include regular servicing, 24/7 support, and emergency call-out services. When choosing a MaaS provider, it is important to consider their experience, reputation, and the range of services they offer. You should also make sure that you are clear about the terms of the agreement, including any charges for call-outs or other services.
So if you're in the market for a new machine, but don't want the hassle of owning one, consider a machine as a service. It just might be the perfect solution for you.

<![CDATA[Today is special day celebrated around the world but specially in Serbia. Why?
It's an Armistice Day. A day which we commemorate every year on 11th November to mark the armistice signed between the Allies of World War I and Germany at CompiÃ¨gne, France, at 5:45 am for the cessation of hostilities on the Western Front of World War I, which took effect at eleven in the morningâ€”the "eleventh hour of the eleventh day of the eleventh month" of 1918.
To commemorate their victims, people in Serbia wear Natalie's Ramonda as a symbol of remembrance. It is an endangered species that grows in eastern Serbia and on the highest peak of KajmakÄalan, where the Serbian army under the command of Duke Å½ivojin MiÅ¡iÄ‡ fought fiercely against the Bulgarians on Thessaloniki front to create conditions for breakthrough. The symbolism of the flower is multiple, and it is also known as the phoenix flower, because even if it dries completely when watered, it can come to life, which symbolically indicates the resurrection of the Serbian state from the ashes after the First World War.
Serbia paid a disproportionately high price for the victory in the Great War. The Serbian forces suffered the largest casualty rate in World War I. In one of the most terrible conflicts the world has ever seen, according to the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, Serbia lost 1.247.435 people, or 28 percent of the total population it had according to the 1914 census, or 60 percent of the male population.
On the 11th of November Serbia remembers with pride and reverence hundreds of thousands of civilians and warriors, innocently and heroically killed in the battles for the defence and liberation of the homeland during the four war years. ]]>

Intelligent-automation solutions can help to achieve efficiency and effectiveness gains, and support decision making by extracting new insights from complex data. Specifically, different aspects of system development and operation (such as implementation and system management, risk and resilience management, and business-process optimization) are often managed by various functions in a fragmented way. Furthermore, organizations typically lack robust frameworks, processes, and infrastructure to ensure the effective risk and return assessment of AI and automation. <![CDATA[Why Becoming a Data-Driven Organization Is So Hard?
Companies have been working to become more data-driven for many years at this point, with mixed results. These efforts play out over time in organizations, and persistence, resilience, execution, and a relentless drive to employ data to make more informed business decisions are what distinguishes those companies that prevail from those who continue to struggle.
Right now, the biggest challenge for organizations working on their data strategy might not have to do with technology at all. In the latest NewVantage Partners annual survey, which tracks the progress of corporate data initiatives, corporate chief data, information, and analytics executives reported that cultural change is the most critical business imperative. Itâ€™s an understandable problem: to a degree that is perpetually underestimated, becoming data-driven is about the ability of people and organizations to adapt to change. Long-established companies, which have been successful over generations or centuries, are unlikely to change overnight â€” adoption of the internet through digital transformation efforts has played out over the course of the past quarter century. Similarly, the effort by companies to become data-driven represents a business transformation that is playing out over the course of a generation. Much has been achieved, yet more remains to be done.
Becoming a data-driven organization is a journey, which unfolds over time, measured in years, and sometimes decades. What steps can organizations and business leaders take to accelerate these efforts? Experience tells us that data-driven organizations consistently demonstrate qualities that distinguish them from their contemporaries. Data-driven companies consistently execute on these three driving principles:

item.title: Post 502
item.description:
<![CDATA[Digital transformation is becoming increasingly important for retailers to stay competitive in today's fast-paced business environment. One of the most promising technologies in this space is the Digital Twin. A Digital Twin is a virtual replica of an object, process, or system that allows retailers to simulate and analyze real-world scenarios, improving efficiency, reducing costs, and driving revenue growth.
According to a study by Accenture, ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—¼ ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ—± ğ——ğ—¶ğ—´ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—§ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—» ğ˜ğ—²ğ—°ğ—µğ—»ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ˜† ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—²ğ—» ğ—®ğ—» ğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—´ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—³ ğŸ¯ğŸ¬% ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—²ğ—³ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜†, ğŸ®ğŸ¬% ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ğ˜€, ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğŸ­ğŸ±% ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜€ğ—² ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—»ğ˜‚ğ—².
Using Digital Twin technology in retail can help improve inventory management by providing real-time data on stock levels and sales trends, allowing retailers to optimize inventory and reduce waste. Additionally, Digital Twins can simulate store layouts, helping retailers to optimize store design and layout to improve the customer experience, leading to increased sales and customer loyalty.
Digital Twin technology can also be used in supply chain management, allowing retailers to optimize logistics and reduce costs. By simulating supply chain scenarios, retailers can identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies and take steps to address them. This can help retailers to improve their delivery time and customer satisfaction.
However, it's important to note that the implementation of Digital Twin technology should be part of a broader digital transformation strategy. To ensure success, retailers should involve internal stakeholders, address concerns about job loss, and have a deep understanding of how the changes will affect the customer experience. It's also important for retailers to consider the risks and challenges associated with digital transformation, such as cyber threats and data privacy concerns, and implement the necessary measures to mitigate them.
Digital Twin technology is still in the early stages of adoption in the retail industry, but the potential benefits are clear. Retailers who are looking to stay ahead of the curve and drive growth should consider how they can leverage this technology to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and enhance the customer experience.
For more information on how to use Digital Twin in the Digital Transformation of Retail, you can check the following link: https://lnkd.in/e9bC4jBP

item.title: Post 496
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is a Blue Ocean strategy?
A Blue Ocean strategy is a business strategy that is used in order to create new demand in an uncontested market space. This strategy is used in order to avoid the intense competition that is usually seen in markets that have been well established. The goal of a blue ocean strategy is to create new demand in a market that doesn't exist yet.
In order to create a blue ocean, businesses need to first understand the difference between value and price. Value is the combination of benefits that a customer receives from a product or service. Price is the amount of money that a customer is willing to pay for a product or service. In order to create a blue ocean, businesses need to focus on creating value for their customers.
There are four steps that businesses need to take in order to create a blue ocean:
1. Define what your company does in terms of the customer experience 2. Map out the current state of the customer experience 3. Identify areas for improvement in the customer experience 4. Create a plan to improve the customer experience
By following these steps, businesses can create a blue ocean strategy that will help them to avoid the intense competition in well-established markets and create new demand in markets that don't exist yet.
#blueocean #digitaltransformation #strategy #businesstransformation #newmarkets #newway #consultancy ]]>

<![CDATA[Why Becoming a Data-Driven Organization Is So Hard?
Companies have been working to become more data-driven for many years at this point, with mixed results. These efforts play out over time in organizations, and persistence, resilience, execution, and a relentless drive to employ data to make more informed business decisions are what distinguish those companies that prevail from those who continue to struggle.
Right now, the biggest challenge for organizations working on their data strategy might not have to do with technology at all. In the latest NewVantage Partners annual survey, which tracks the progress of corporate data initiatives, corporate chief data, information, and analytics executives reported that cultural change is the most critical business imperative. Itâ€™s an understandable problem: to the degree that is perpetually underestimated, becoming data-driven is about the ability of people and organizations to adapt to change. Long-established companies, which have been successful over generations or centuries, are unlikely to change overnight â€” the adoption of the internet through digital transformation efforts has played out over the course of the past quarter century. Similarly, the effort by companies to become data-driven represents a business transformation that is playing out over the course of a generation. Much has been achieved, yet more remains to be done.
Becoming a data-driven organization is a journey, which unfolds over time, measured in years, and sometimes decades. What steps can organizations and business leaders take to accelerate these efforts? Experience tells us that data-driven organizations consistently demonstrate qualities that distinguish them from their contemporaries. Data-driven companies consistently execute these three driving principles:
1. Think different. 2. Fail fast, learn faster. 3. Focus on the long-term.

<![CDATA[What is Lights-Out Manufacturing?
Where traditional factories and even smart factories require some direct human interaction, true lights-out factories operate completely autonomously.
Though it might sound like a dream, lights-out factories are fully automated, 24/7 factories with no on-floor human presence. And they already exist in the modern world.
Japanese robotics designer FANUC has been using robots to build themselves in a lights-out factory for 20 years, and even electronics company Philips uses 128 robots in a lights-out manufacturing line to produce electric razors.
One industry that uses lights-out manufacturing extensively is semiconductor manufacturing. ASE Global, the worldâ€™s leading provider of semiconductor manufacturing services in assembly and test, used 18 completely automated factories in 2020 alone.
Which industries will implement lights-out manufacturing? New robot installations in 2019 show that the automotive, electronics, and metal and machinery sectors are unsurprisingly leading the way in Industry 4.0 implementation.

In software, that means applications arenâ€™t so much deliverables as they are ongoing relationships. item.title: Post 481
item.description:
<![CDATA[Machine learning (ML) model development requires a carefully designed workflow to ensure that the resulting algorithm is both effective and reliable. One critical step in this process is the collection of a large set of sensor data that represents both healthy and faulty operations, collected under different operating conditions. By doing so, the ML model will be better equipped to detect faults more effectively and accurately.
In some cases, there may not be enough data available to represent a healthy and faulty machine. To overcome this, a mathematical model of the machine can be built and its parameters estimated based on the sensor data. This digital twin model can then be used to simulate the real-world system to model the reliability of the machine under different fault states and operating conditions.
By following a robust workflow, companies can develop ML models that can detect faults more effectively, leading to better outcomes, increased efficiency, and cost savings.

<![CDATA[Cloud computing, AI, data analytics, automation and cybersecurity have emerged as the five essential workplace technologies based on C-suite investment priorities.
While each of these technologies is at a different stage of development, the extent to which they complement and enable one another holds possible implications for their ability to attract future investments.
Firms can invest in AI solutions but need data to make AI function. Digital data isnâ€™t exactly physical, but it doesnâ€™t exist in the ether either â€” it needs a physical storage place. For the sake of cost and convenience, most firms have decided that at least some of that storage place should exist in the cloud. Companies donâ€™t just need raw data, they need data that has been organised, categorised and analysed. And all of this new digital scaffolding needs to be protected. <![CDATA[Growth remains a key driver of success for businesses of all sizes and across all industries. The 'Three Horizons of Growth' model, developed by McKinsey and IFF, provides a framework to help companies anticipate and plan growth into the future.
This model is comprised of Horizon 1, 2, and 3 and has seen significant success, with 83 percent of executives reporting that it has enabled their organizations to outperform their peers.
Horizon 1 (â€˜Keeping the lights onâ€˜) focuses on maintaining and improving existing products and markets, Horizon 2 (â€˜Building future venturesâ€˜) focuses on developing new products and entering new markets, and Horizon 3 (â€˜Imagining the futureâ€˜) focuses on breakthrough products for entirely new markets.
Embracing this model and making it part of a business strategy will create a sustainable framework for growth.

item.title: Post 472
item.description:
<![CDATA[â“What is prescriptive maintenance?
Decision Intelligence is the most advanced result of Artificial Intelligence techniques applied to risk mitigation processes and the achievement of objectives
ğŸ“ˆ Maintenance now plays a central role in the management of complex machines and systems. In modern plants, it is in fact increasingly important to guarantee pre-established levels of productivity and availability also in consideration of the fact that these are often parameters included in the contractual terms.
ğŸ’¡ Industry 4.0 and Artificial Intelligence are making a truly significant contribution to the evolution of maintenance, which has gone from a purely reactive operation to a preventive, predictive and finally prescriptive operation. This evolution is fundamental for identifying and controlling the risks associated with the operational life cycle of complex systems by organizations, both in terms of magnitude and frequency of unwanted events. And it is precisely in this context that the new machine learning techniques of Industry 4.0, based on Artificial Intelligence, can represent a valuable tool for automating the analysis of large amounts of data from plants and machinery and for prevention of associated risks.
ğŸ¯ This new approach to maintenance, which represents the most modern evolution of predictive maintenance, offers the opportunity not only to predict the onset of problems and failures but also to prescribe solutions and provide decision support, identifying actions to be undertaken and selecting the optimal risk management policy in terms of safety, availability, profitability and sustainability.
Prescriptive maintenance, therefore, makes it possible to simulate alternative scenarios on the basis of certain actions and to evaluate their impact both from a financial and safety point of view, along different time horizons and under certain conditions. In this way, it is possible to calibrate decisions such as the decommissioning of a specific structure, the replacement of a system to reach the end of life, the remodelling of the amortization plan and the revision of some items of the income statement. Thanks to the possibility of making inferences, that is to draw deductive conclusions, supported by Artificial Intelligence in a decision-making network, Decision Intelligence also allows for the evaluation of the possible impacts of simulations including the "Life cycle assessment" and the "life cycle cost".

item.title: Post 468
item.description:
<![CDATA[â“How can you flip the odds of digital transformation success?
With so much at stake to build digital capabilities that drive customer centricity and productivity, why do so many companies fail? And not just troubled companiesâ€”top performers, market leaders, and investor favourites, too. Research by Boston Consulting Group (BCG) shows that 70% of digital transformations fall short of their objectives, often with profound consequences.
ğŸ“ˆDigital leaders achieve earnings growth that is 1.8 times higher than digital laggardsâ€”and more than double the growth in total enterprise value. In the short term, digital technologies and working methods offer productivity improvements and better customer experiences. In the medium term, digital opens up new growth opportunities and business model innovation. Successful transformations also set companies up for sustained success; they wonâ€™t have to digitally transform again as they master continuous innovation. Investors say that 50% of companies should invest more aggressively in digital capabilities and technology.
But there is a conundrum for management: digital transformations are difficult to execute. And with so much on the line, only 30% of transformations succeed in achieving their objectives. There are good reasons for this, too. Technology is important, but the people dimension (organization, operating model, processes, and culture) is usually the determining factor. Organizational inertia from deeply rooted behaviours is a big impediment.
Failure should not be an option, and yet it is the most common result. The consequences in terms of investments of money, organizational effort, and elapsed time are massive. Digital laggards fall behind in customer engagement, process efficiency, and innovation.
When trying to bring everyone along with the overall plan, it can be easy to compromise and lose focus on the transformational aspiration. This is where the trouble usually starts. But among all the decisions that must be made, six critical success factors stand out. The companies that get these six factors right flip their odds of success from 30% to 80%.
ğŸ¯The six essential success factors are:
1. An Integrated Strategy with Clear Transformation Goals. 2. Leadership Commitment from CEO Through Middle Management. 3. Deploying High-Calibre Talent. 4. An Agile Governance Mindset That Drives Broader Adoption. 5. Effective Monitoring of Progress Toward Defined Outcomes. 6. Business-Led Modular Technology and Data Platform.

<![CDATA[How to prepare companies for the future? By reinventing the organization!
The management concepts that the org chart visualizesâ€”coordination, hierarchy, a matrixed organizationâ€”are the one's leaders grew up with and know best, as did generations before them. The original org chart hailed from 1854 and was introduced to help run the New York and Erie Railroad during the age of the steam locomotive.
Therein lies the challenge. Todayâ€™s organizations are set up as traditional hierarchies or matrix organizations with roots stretching back to the industrial revolutions of the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries. In theory, these structures provide clear lines of authority from frontline employees up through layers of management. In reality, matrix structures have only grown more complex as the business hasâ€”to the extent that in some companies they are so cumbersome they hardly function.

The system has six levels of automation and spans a yawning gulf of features. Level zero is analogous to Fred Flintstoneâ€™s foot-powered, stone-age car, while level five is something like George Jetsonâ€™s futuristic, bubble-blowing flying saucer.

As a result, analytics tools have grown in importance. Manufacturers can gain greater, more timely insights with analytics at the edge and in the cloud, allowing them to improve operational performance and, as a result, increase revenue and margins.
A manufacturer can develop additional, pertinent service offerings for each customer with more insight into the products installed at their sites, such as maintenance contracts that allow the manufacturer to monitor customers' equipment and guarantee it is always operating at peak efficiency. For the manufacturer, this means additional revenue streams. The manufacturer also avoids the needâ€”and related expenseâ€”for equipment covered by a warranty to be shipped to a facility for repair by using this equipment data to proactively identify and fix potential issues before they become problems. As a result, fewer warranty claims affect the company's bottom line.
Paradoxically, the main obstacle to using analytics in manufacturing is also its opportunity: the need for proof of value. We observe that businesses frequently start with proofs of concept and precise analytics applications, i.e., the areas where the opportunity is most naturally apparent.
Security issues represent another barrier. Protecting those capabilities and limiting access to the underlying data related to them are essential for sectors like high tech, where intellectual property (IP) related to manufacturing capability and process design is essential to success.
Additionally, there are obstacles caused by disconnected systems and a limited or non-existent flow of structured data within systems. The skills people have to use these new toolsâ€”which are frequently lacking or need to be strengthenedâ€”and their willingness to adopt new technology are the most frequent risks or barriers.

<![CDATA[One of the key enablers of this Industry 4.0 is the Internet of Things (IoT), which allows for real-time monitoring and control of all production assets and data-driven optimization of productivity and quality. This is similar to how the steam age or the electric age (the first and second industrial revolutions, respectively) brought about radical improvements in efficiency.
McKinsey estimates that IoT applications in factory settings could generate a value of $ğŸ­.ğŸ® ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—¼ $ğŸ¯.ğŸ³ ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜†ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¿ ğ—¯ğ˜† ğŸ®ğŸ¬ğŸ®ğŸ±. Their research suggests that the largest value creation opportunity will be in operations optimizationâ€”enhancing the performance of various processes within the factory. This includes using sensors, instead of human intervention (and human error), to fine-tune the operation of machinery. It also involves using data from production equipment to optimize workflows. This is achieved by remotely tracking, monitoring, and adjusting machines, based on sensor data from different parts of the plant (and even across plants).
Overall, IoT applications in operations optimization could create a value of $633 billion to $1.8 trillion per year in the factory setting by 2025.
Besides operations optimization, the other major value drivers of IoT in the factory setting are predictive maintenance and inventory optimization. Predictive maintenance uses sensors to continuously observe machinery to prevent failures and determine when maintenance is needed, rather than relying on fixed maintenance schedules. IoT can improve inventory management by automatically replenishing parts bins based on weight or height data captured by sensors.

item.title: Post 441
item.description:
<![CDATA[Do you know that Additive Manufacturing (or 3D printing) is a greener substitute to traditional manufacturing?
AM has four general environmental advantages over conventional or subtractive manufacturing: â€¢ material efficiency, â€¢ resource efficiency, â€¢ production flexibility and â€¢ part flexibility.
Unlike subtractive manufacturing in which waste material is removed to reveal a product, AM only creates what is needed for the product with minimal support structure. Resource efficiencies refer to how generally simplistic AM machines are. Conventional machinery often requires auxiliary tools, equipment and coolants, which utilize energy and generate emissions and waste. Because AM has less need for ancillary equipment than do conventional machines, AM requires fewer resources, and therefore has fewer energy needs. Also, because these ancillary tools and equipment are not needed for production, parts can be made by smaller manufacturers located closer to users, thus reducing transportation costs and related emissions. Part flexibility is a major waste reduction aspect of AM. The ability to make on-demand products reduces inventory and other wastes. Finally, production flexibility, or the ability to quickly switch between different products without costly or time-consuming setup, allows a more streamlined supply chain and economical production batches to meet customer needs.
One significant way that AM reduces waste in the manufacturing industry is by the inherent made-to-order technology. Inventory waste reduction and fewer unsold products can be taken advantage of due to small-batch orders and only producing as many items as are requested. Companies have capitalized on making spare parts with the made-to-order technology, and can generate less high-value waste. In fact, it is estimated that up to $370 billion in savings will occur by 2025 from the reduction of input material and a shorter supply chain (Ford & Despeisse, 2016).
Do you use AM in your company? Pyron Technology can support you with decision on AM implementation and best usage.

<![CDATA[Do you use design thinking approach to develop products or services?
Design thinking is an innovative problem-solving process rooted in a set of skills. The approach has been around for decades.
At a high level, the steps involved in the design thinking process are simple: first, fully understand the problem; second, explore a wide range of possible solutions; third, iterate extensively through prototyping and testing; and finally, implement through the customary deployment mechanisms.
The skills associated with these steps help people apply creativity to effectively solve real-world problems better than they otherwise would. They can be readily learned, but take effort.
Creative brainstorming is necessary for developing possible solutions, but many people donâ€™t do it particularly well. And throughout the process it is critical to engage in modelling, analysis, prototyping, and testing, and to really learn from these many iterations.

item.title: Post 436
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is the strategic business value of using blockchain in different industries?
With all the hype around blockchain, it can be hard to nail down the facts. Blockchain is a distributed ledger, or database, shared across a public or private computing network. Each computer node in the network holds a copy of the ledger, so there is no single point of failure. Every piece of information is mathematically encrypted and added as a new â€œblockâ€ to the chain of historical records. Various consensus protocols are used to validate a new block with other participants before it can be added to the chain. This prevents fraud or double spending without requiring a central authority. The ledger can also be programmed with â€œsmart contracts,â€ a set of conditions recorded on the blockchain so that transactions automatically trigger when the conditions are met. For example, smart contracts could be used to automate insurance-claim payouts.
The potential for blockchain to become a new open-standard protocol for trusted records, identity, and transactions cannot be simply dismissed. Blockchain technology can solve the need for an entity to be in charge of managing, storing, and funding a database. True peer-to-peer models can become commercially viable due to blockchainâ€™s ability to compensate participants for their contributions with â€œtokensâ€ (application-specific cryptoassets) as well as give them a stake in any future increases in the value. However, the mentality shift required and the commercial disruption such a model would entail are immense.
Blockchain might have the disruptive potential to be the basis of new operating models, but its initial impact will be to drive operational efficiencies. Cost can be taken out of existing processes by removing intermediaries or the administrative effort of record keeping and transaction reconciliation. This can shift the flow of value by capturing lost revenues and creating new revenues for blockchain-service providers. Based on McKinsey & Company's quantification of the monetary impact of the more than 90 use cases analysed, it is estimated that approximately 70% of the value at stake in the short term is in cost reduction, followed by revenue generation and capital relief.

Strategy can quickly become out of date in an increasingly volatile and uncertain world. Strategic planning must be adaptive in order to address this challenge. The more adaptive your strategy models must be, the faster the rate of change in operating conditions and the more disruptions you must integrate into a long-term strategy.
An adaptive strategy approach ensures that your organisation can spot new opportunities earlier and respond faster than competitors, increasing your chances of success in a dynamic digital world.
A truly adaptive strategy approach adheres to four core practices that are intended to transition the enterprise from a rigid, top-down, calendar-based process to a more event-driven strategy approach. The same principles can be applied to functional strategy. While a truly adaptive approach will incorporate all four core practises, functional leaders can begin by concentrating on the practises that address their immediate strategy challenges.
Rather than requiring perfect or complete information to execute, the adaptive strategy makes use of available data to identify immediate actions needed for an enterprise or function to succeed. These actions could include focusing on high-priority areas, making foundational investments, or running experiments to test ideas. You can use the insights gained from these actions, as well as any new information or analysis, to determine your next set of actions.
Because adaptive strategy necessitates reviewing strategy whenever new (and relevant) information becomes available, it's critical to constantly scan the business context for changes and review â€” and, if necessary, adjust â€” strategy in response to changes.

A data lake, as defined by Gartner, is a treasure trove of raw, unstructured data. â†³ Think of it as a well-organized library where every book has a code.
A data swamp is what happens when the library gets disorganized. â†³ Imagine trying to find a book without a catalogue - pure chaos.
Data lakes are searchable, thanks to metadata; swamps are not. â†³ Metadata is like a library's index card, guiding you to the right shelf.
Lakes have data governance; swamps have data anarchy. â†³ Good governance in data is like having librarians who know exactly where each book belongs.
Cleansing strategies keep lakes pristine; swamps are murky with errors. â†³ Without regular cleaning, even the best library turns into a garage sale.
Organized, relevant data defines a lake; irrelevant clutter characterizes a swamp. â†³ A pristine lake is full of fish; a swamp is just... swampy.
Governance is the dividing line - it ensures quality and relevance. â†³ Governance is the difference between a well-run library and a room full of old newspapers.
Avoid transforming your data lake into a swamp:
â€¢ Less is more. Focus on quality data, not quantity. â€¢ Let automation handle the cleanup. â€¢ Define the data's purpose early to streamline relevance.
Remember, an ocean of data is useless if you can't navigate through it. Metadata is becoming easier to manage, so invest in it.
ğŸ“Œ Your data strategy is as crucial as the data itself.
In the end, a data lake is a source of truth, easily navigable; a data swamp is a maze of misinformation.
Choose wisely, manage effectively, and let your data strategy reflect the clarity of a lake, not the confusion of a swamp.
