<![CDATA[âš¡Creating and implementing a ğ—•ğ—¶ğ—´ ğ——ğ—®ğ˜ğ—® ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—´ğ˜† is a difficult task for organisations, especially if they lack a data-driven culture.
Such a culture is required for the successful implementation of a Big Data strategy. According to this roadmap, the best way to get started with Big Data is to first understand what it is and what it can do for your organisation, and then work with a multidisciplinary team to develop Proof of Concepts. These initial Proof of Concepts are critical for your company's data-driven transformation and should be shared with all employees.
Knowledgent's infographic below depicts five levels of Big Data maturity within an organisation. The first level is referred to as the Infancy phase, and it is the stage at which one begins to understand Big Data and develop Proof of Concepts.
The second level they identified is the technical adoption phase, in which the company prepares to implement various Big Data technologies. These technologies, whether on-premises or in the cloud, will allow a company to develop new Proof of Concepts / products or Big Data services more quickly and effectively.
An organisation enters level 3 of the Big Data maturity index once the IT department is capable of working with Big Data technologies and the business understands what Big Data can do for them. More in-depth analysis of structured and unstructured data available within the company will result in more insights and better decision-making.
Level 4 is where Big Data analytics has become an integral part of the company's culture and has resulted in integrated predictive insights into business operations. This is the final level before becoming a fully data-driven organisation that operates as a "data service provider." Companies that have achieved level 5 of the Big Data maturity index have integrated Big Data analytics at all levels of their organisation, are truly data-driven, and can be considered 'data companies' regardless of the product or service they provide. Based on their Big Data insights, they will significantly outperform their competitors.
âš¡All businesses should strive for Big Data maturity level 5 because it will lead to better decision-making, better products, and better service.

item.title: Post 401
item.description:
<![CDATA[The world today is still largely driven by the principles of the Linear Economy, which is based on a take-make-dispose model. However, this model is proving to be unsustainable for our one and only precious planet, and it is high time that we embrace the Circular Economy model. The Circular Economy aims to minimize waste and maximize the use of resources, through strategies such as reuse, repair, and recycling.
By adopting sustainable practices and transitioning towards the Circular Economy model, companies can not only reduce their environmental footprint, but also achieve significant cost savings, boost their brand reputation, and enhance customer loyalty. Sustainability and digital transformation go hand in hand, as digital technologies can be leveraged to optimize resource use and enable more efficient and sustainable operations.
Through digital transformation, companies can use data analytics, automation, and artificial intelligence to monitor and manage their resource use, reduce waste, and improve their energy efficiency. This can also enable them to track their progress towards sustainability targets, comply with regulations, and report on their environmental performance.
By embracing sustainability and the Circular Economy model, companies can not only contribute to a healthier planet, but also create long-term value for their stakeholders, including customers, employees, investors, and society as a whole.

<![CDATA[When you think of digital twins, you may be picturing a new product, a fantastic technology or even a business model.
But there are also many other scenarios where digital twins are used as a way to measure and improve the performance of an existing product.
A digital twin is a virtual representation that serves as the real-time digital counterpart of a physical object or process. The virtual twin is disrupting the entire product lifecycle management (PLM), from design to manufacturing to service and operations. The logic behind this is that any time there is a link between physical objects and processes, the potential for performance improvement exists.
Digital twins can provide enterprises with cost benefits by â€¢ reducing machine downtime, â€¢ decreasing inventory holding costs, â€¢ improving efficiency, â€¢ increasing quality, â€¢ empowering customers, â€¢ saving space, â€¢ improving productivity, â€¢ saving energy, â€¢ improving process automation, â€¢ expanding market reach by providing more value for customers at lower costs than traditional solutions such as paper-based records which consume up to 80% of all energy produced during their production cycle; â€¢ lowering purchase price tags by enabling smaller organizations to deal primarily with small volumes.

item.title: Post 388
item.description:
<![CDATA[Companies often assume that if they embrace digital technology in any way, theyâ€™re digitally transforming their business. As a result, they often make only ad hoc changes and investments in the digital arena, with ineffectual results. The challenge, to which most companies have yet to rise, is figuring out how to fully capture the different kinds of value that these technologies offer.
Developing a strategy for digital transformation that fully leverages this value is also not easy. Without a comprehensive assessment of what digital technologies can offer, firms tend to assume that any application of modern digital technologies will lead to a digital transformation.
Defined by Harvard Business Review there are four distinct tiers of digital transformation, each of which meets different strategic objectives and allows companies to maximize the value they capture from digital technologies:
1. Tier One: Operational efficiencies 2. Tier Two: Advanced operational efficiencies 3. Tier Three: Data-driven services from value chains 4. Tier Four: Data-driven services from digital platforms
To think properly about these four tiers of transformation, the first step is to recognize that modern digital technologies have two notable value drivers: data in its new expansive role, and emergent digital ecosystems.

<![CDATA[Digital maturity is the level of an organization's digitization or better said a measure of an organizationâ€™s ability to create value through digital.
This includes the extent to which an organization uses digital technologies, as well as the organization's overall readiness to face digital transformation. According to a study by McKinsey, the average company is only 20 per cent digitalized. This means that, on average, companies are only using digital technologies for 20 per cent of their operations. This low level of digital maturity is a major problem for businesses. In today's digital world, companies must be able to use digital technologies to remain competitive.
There are a number of different ways to assess digital maturity and all include holistic assessments of the business. There are many benefits to assessing the digital maturity of enterprises. By doing so, companies can identify areas where they need to improve their digital capabilities. Additionally, digital maturity assessments can help organizations benchmark their progress and compare themselves to other companies. At the beginning of a digital transformation, companies use digital maturity assessments to holistically assess the businesses by covering many categories, such as customer journeys, digital supply chain, marketing personalization, governance, innovation, technology, customer, operations, and people. This early benchmarking becomes exponentially more valuable over the course of a digital transformation as companies track digital growth to identify where theyâ€™re gaining traction and where theyâ€™re falling behind. Businesses with high levels of digital maturity have a competitive advantage along multiple performance indicators, including revenue growth, time to market, cost efficiency, product quality, and customer satisfaction. Businesses with low levels of digital maturity struggle to achieve these benefits. Digital maturity assessments can be beneficial for companies of all sizes. By assessing their digital maturity, companies can identify areas where they need to improve and make changes to become more digital.
Given digitalâ€™s continued contribution to company performance, the gap between digital leaders and laggards will likely grow.

item.title: Post 370
item.description:
<![CDATA[Creating a clear path to Industry 4.0 transformation
Based on its experience with industrial clients, MIT Sloan School of Management has developed a strategy to avoid falling into the trap of purchasing technology that is underutilised or fails to deliver the desired business outcomes. It is recommended for a more gradual transition process that incorporates systems thinking and addresses cultural norms.
This will translate lofty Industry 4.0 visions into actionable strategies and next steps to improve internal processes. The following are important steps:
The initial stages of transformation will be driven by ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€. Manufacturers frequently install networks of hundreds of sensors and then return to solve a specific problem. Problems are not solved by technology. In fact, technology has the potential to exacerbate problems by increasing data overload and eroding employees' trust in the new system.

<![CDATA[Unlocking the Potential of Digital Transformation: A Roadmap for Success
In the digital era, transformation is not just about cloud migration or SaaSâ€”it's a complete integration of technology into the core of the business, reshaping value delivery. Yet, many attempts to transform still fall short. Let's change that narrative. Here are six pivotal steps for a successful digital transformation:
1. Outcome-Focused Strategy: Start with a clear strategic plan centred on outcomes, considering both immediate and long-term goals. Link digital transformation to mission outcomes to enhance operations, employee experiences, and customer service. Prioritize security and compliance for scalability and resilience.
2. Domain-Experienced Talent: Select team members with industry, business, or specific domain knowledge. For example, military experience for defence systems, business acumen for revenue projects, or data science expertise for AI initiatives. Blend talent with domain experience to boost team cohesion, communication, and swift decision-making.
3. User-Centric Adoption Plan: Success is when users embrace and weave technology into their daily tasks. Foster user enthusiasm by involving them in the transformation process, ensuring a smoother transition at launch.
4. Revise Outdated Processes: Update or eliminate old processes and policies that don't align with the new digital workflows. Prepare policies and workflows in advance for seamless user adoption, executed in incremental phases.
5. Organizational Alignment: Secure enterprise-wide agreement from the top down. Understand that transformation is a phased journey requiring long-term dedication. This consensus will mitigate the impact of shifting priorities and emergencies.
6. Agile and Resilient Approach: Adopt agile methodologies for continuous, iterative releases, allowing for prompt feedback and adjustments. Embrace a "fail fast" mindset to stay aligned with market and technological advancements.

item.title: Post 352
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is RPA?
RPA is a form of business process automation where software robots are used to carry out repetitive and rules-based tasks. RPA can be used to automate a wide range of tasks, including data entry, data mining, and process monitoring.
RPA is becoming increasingly popular as businesses look for ways to automate low-value tasks and free up employees to focus on more strategic work. RPA software is typically easy to use and can be deployed quickly, making it a cost-effective solution for many organizations.
When considering RPA, it is important to understand the capabilities of the software and how it can be used to benefit your business. This introduction will provide an overview of RPA, its key features, and common use cases.
What are the key features of RPA?
RPA software typically includes the following features:
- A user interface that allows users to configure the software to carry out specific tasks - A set of tools for developing and testing automation scripts - The ability to integrate with existing business applications - A library of pre-built automation scripts
What are the benefits of RPA?
RPA can provide a number of benefits for businesses, including:
- Increased efficiency: RPA can be used to automate tasks that are currently being carried out manually, such as data entry and process monitoring. This can help to improve efficiency and free up employees to focus on other tasks.
- Reduced costs: RPA can help to reduce the cost of business processes by eliminating the need for manual labor.
- Improved compliance: RPA can be used to automate compliance-related tasks, such as auditing and report generation. This can help to improve an organization's compliance posture.
- Greater agility: RPA can help businesses to quickly adapt to changes in business processes. For example, if a new regulation is introduced, RPA can be used to automatically update the relevant business processes.
What are the common use cases for RPA?
RPA can be used to automate a wide range of tasks. Some common use cases for RPA include:
- Data entry: RPA can be used to automatically populate data fields in business applications.
- Data mining: RPA can be used to extract data from multiple sources and compile it into a single format.
- Process monitoring: RPA can be used to monitor business processes and identify areas of improvement.
- Report generation: RPA can be used to generate reports based on data from multiple sources.
Other possible ideas are given on the picture.
#rpa #digitaltransformation #businesstransformation #automation #robot #optimization #process]]>

item.title: Post 345
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is Business Process Management and how it helps digital transformation?
Technologies that challenge the status quo are those that enable digital transformation. Digital transformation is a process of using technology to create new or improved business processes, products, or services. This can be done in order to reduce costs, improve efficiency, or create new revenue streams.
Digital transformation can be enabled by a number of different technologies, including cloud computing, artificial intelligence, big data, and the Internet of Things. These technologies can challenge the status quo by making it possible to do things that were previously not possible, or by making existing processes more efficient.
The benefits of digital transformation can be significant. For example, Accenture estimates that digital transformation can help companies achieve a 30 percent reduction in costs. McKinsey has found that companies that have embraced digital transformation are 26 percent more profitable than their peers.
However, digital transformation can also be disruptive. It can challenge existing business models and lead to the need for new skills and processes. As such, it is important for companies to carefully consider how they can best take advantage of digital transformation while minimizing its risks.
Innovation and constant breakthroughs in the worlds of business and IT mean that the status quo of running a business is constantly shifting. BPM (Business Process Management) itself has shifted from a one-time initiative to a constant process.
#bpm #businessprocess #businesstransformation #digitaltransformation #rpa #innovation #process #optimisation #business #digital #technology #efficiency]]>

item.description:
<![CDATA[Creating a clear path to Industry 4.0 transformation
Based on its experience with industrial clients, MIT Sloan School of Management has developed a strategy to avoid falling into the trap of purchasing technology that is underutilised or fails to deliver the desired business outcomes. It is recommended for a more gradual transition process that incorporates systems thinking and addresses cultural norms.
This will translate lofty Industry 4.0 visions into actionable strategies and next steps to improve internal processes. The following are important steps:
The initial stages of transformation will be driven by ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ˜ ğ—ºğ—®ğ—»ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€. Manufacturers frequently install networks of hundreds of sensors and then return to solve a specific problem. Problems are not solved by technology. In fact, technology has the potential to exacerbate problems by increasing data overload and eroding employees' trust in the new system.
Instead of launching a full-scale network with hundreds of sensors, a more cautious approach that focuses on a specific problem and uses Industry 4.0 capabilities to solve it is recommended. Engaging employees to identify critical stress points in their jobs, as well as evaluating processes to identify opportunities for improvement and value creation, is critical for larger transformation.
Begin by "ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—²ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´" ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—³ğ—²ğ—²ğ—±ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—°ğ—¸ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—ºğ—¶ğ˜€ğ˜€ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´. Knowing where to establish a feedback loop is critical to the business value of Industry 4.0, but the question is where to begin. The hunt for hidden factories can be fruitful because it allows you to listen to the system and identify the most significant gaps. It is also critical to implement processes that reduce the time between measurement and action. Data collected in a database or spreadsheet is insufficient to drive change.
ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—² ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ˜ğ—²ğ—°ğ—µğ—»ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—½ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—µğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—¶ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ ğ˜‚ğ—»ğ˜€ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜€ğ˜†ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—²ğ—ºğ˜€. <![CDATA[ğŸ¤– The digital age has brought about a significant shift in the way we work. Previously, we celebrated individual achievements, but now, we prioritize team collaboration.
â“Why?
Because the perfect blend of technology and teamwork is essential for creating the businesses of tomorrow.
The focus has shifted from personal interactions to digital ones.
The office environment has transformed, and remote working is now the norm. However, team spirit has remained a crucial factor in keeping us motivated. The effectiveness of the technology we use depends on how well we can collaborate with it.
It's important to understand that communication is not the same as collaboration. While you may be communicating regularly with your team through chat apps, video platforms, and task trackers, it's the depth of your collaborative ties that determines how effectively you can use these tools.

item.title: Post 304
item.description:
<![CDATA[Strategy is, in essence, problem solving, and the best approach depends upon the specific problem at hand. Your environment dictates your approach to strategy. You need to assess the environment and then match and apply the appropriate approach. But how do you characterize the business environment, and how do you choose which approach to strategy is best suited to the job of defining a winning course of action?
Business environments differ along three easily discernible dimensions: 1. Predictability (can you forecast it?), 2. Malleability (can you, either alone or in collaboration with others, shape it?), and 3. Harshness (can you survive it?).
Combining these dimensions into a matrix reveals five distinct environments, each of which requires a distinct approach to strategy and execution.
Each environment corresponds to a distinct archetypal approach to strategy, or colour in the strategy palette, as follows: predictable classical environments lend themselves to strategies of position, which are based on advantage achieved through scale or differentiation or capabilities and are achieved through comprehensive analysis and planning.
Adaptive environments require continuous experimentation because planning does not work under conditions of rapid change and unpredictability. In a visionary setting, firms win by being the first to create a new market or to disrupt an existing one. In a shaping environment, firms can collaboratively shape an industry to their advantage by orchestrating the activities of other stakeholders.
Finally, under the harsh conditions of a renewal environment, a firm needs to first conserve and free up resources to ensure its viability and then go on to choose one of the other four approaches to rejuvenate growth and ensure long-term prosperity (remember COVID19?)
#innovation #businesstransformation #stategy #problemsolving #planning #business #digital #resources]]>

Blockchains are driven by consensus. When a user initiates a transaction, its details are broadcast to the entire network, checked by other users and accepted if there is consensus. Once a transaction has been validated, itâ€™s bundled with other transactions into a block of data.
Each block is secured via a cryptographic algorithm.This results in a unique signature for each block known as a hash. These blocks are then ordered sequentially into a chain of blocks, with each block also containing the previous blockâ€™s hash. This makes it extremely difficult to tamper with a block, as altering a single piece of data would result in a different hash value, making it evident to the blockchainâ€™s users and causing the transaction to be rejected.
Some parts of this process can be done automatically with smart contracts. These involve two entities turning a business contract into code that recognizes actions on the blockchain. For example, a smart contract might recognize that a sale of an asset by â€œCompany Aâ€ to â€œCompany Bâ€ on a certain date should be for a specific price. This simplifies processes that take significant time to check.
This structure gives network participants confidence in their transaction without the need to trust each other.

item.description:
<![CDATA[The process of digital transformation, which involves integrating digital technology into all aspects of a business, is not a one-time event or a finish line to cross but rather an ongoing journey. The reason behind this belief lies in the constant evolution of technology, customer needs, and market dynamics. To remain competitive, businesses need to consistently embrace and adapt to new technologies, tools, and processes.
One of the key reasons why digital transformation is a journey is the rapid growth and evolution of innovative technologies, such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, big data, and cloud computing. These technologies change the way businesses interact with their customers, manage operations, and drive innovation. Companies need to be constantly updating their strategies to keep up with shifts in technological advancements.
An important aspect of the journey is that digital transformation is not just about technology; it's also about culture and mindset. Transitioning into a digital-first business model requires a shift in how employees think, work, and collaborate. Emphasizing continuous learning, encouraging innovation, and adopting agile thinking is essential for fostering a successful digital culture within the organization.
Continuously changing customer expectations are fueling the rise of digital platforms, streamlined experiences, and the need for personalized services. Therefore, companies must keep the customer at the centre of their digital transformation efforts, constantly evolving to meet and exceed their customers' expectations.
Even if companies succeed in implementing the latest technology, they need to be prepared to adapt quickly to future changes. Making digital transformation an ongoing journey helps ensure that organizations remain competitive, agile, and customer-centric.
#DigitalTransformation #BusinessTransformation #TechnologyShift #InnovationCulture #CustomerCentricBusiness #AgileThinking #CustomerExperience #BusinessEvolution ]]>

item.title: Post 273
item.description:
<![CDATA[â“How to coordinate multiple pathways to digital transformation?
Digital transformation can be described as business transformation using digital capabilities. In other words, itâ€™s more than just adopting technology for technologyâ€™s sake. There are four common paths to digital transformation. For some companies, it makes sense to choose more than one.
ğŸ¯ The researchers found that transformation must happen in two ways: better customer experience and improved operational efficiency. Firms can make progress on one, both, or neither, and they typically take four different pathways to transformation:
1. focus on transforming operations, which commonly means building new business services enabled by application programming interfaces (APIs).
2. focus on an integrated customer experience if metrics such as net promoter score fall well below the industry average
3. take incremental steps in each direction over several iterations, starting with a small step to improve the customer experience (such as a new mobile app) and following that with a small step to streamline operations (such as a new customer relationship management system).
4. starting fresh with a spinoff company â€” an option if leaders of the current company donâ€™t think itâ€™s possible to change culture, customer experience, and operations fast enough to survive.
Pathways suited to one business unit might not work for another, and sometimes it makes sense to pursue multiple pathways. One part of the business may need an immediate improvement to customer service, while another may have more latitude to take incremental steps.

item.title: Post 250
item.description:
<![CDATA[How can leaders and teams measure the ROI of innovation projects that involve high uncertainty and unknown business models? In the article by Strategyzer on ROI for innovation it's been discussed that leaders need to understand the difference between the Explore and Exploit worlds of decision-making and allocate resources accordingly.
The Exploit world is where the current successful business operates, with low uncertainty and clear ROI calculations. Also, innovation is about improving and growing the existing business.
The Explore world is where new value propositions and business models are tested, with high uncertainty and no reliable ROI data. In this world, leaders need to use metered funding and evaluate the return on the portfolio, not individual projects.
Leaders are also interested in the time horizon for getting returns from their investments in innovation. In general, the time horizons for Exploit projects are faster than the time horizons for Explore projects.
Efficiency innovation is about doing more with less, sustaining innovation is about making better products for existing customers, and transformative innovation is about creating new markets and customers. Each type of innovation has different implications for growth, profitability, and competitiveness.
#innovation #strategy #leadership #ROI]]>

item.title: Post 225
item.description:
<![CDATA[Whilst it is commonly believed that the principal advantage of artificial intelligence is its ability to provide insights, in actual fact its value lies in its ability to enhance the quality of decision-making. Fortunately, the potential applications of AI in business are practically limitless. Nevertheless, given that decisions made in one area of an organization have the potential to affect other areas, the introduction of AI frequently necessitates the overhaul of entire systems. In this sense, AI is comparable to other revolutionary technologies of the past, such as electricity, which was initially restricted to narrow applications but eventually transformed the manufacturing industry.
Decision-making entails a combination of forecasting and judgment, and since AI is capable of making highly accurate predictions, it has the potential to shift the authority to make decisions towards the area where judgment is still required. This may alter who makes decisions and the time, place and manner in which they are made. The enhanced precision of predictions in one aspect of a value chain will also have a knock-on effect on other aspects. For example, if a manufacturer can accurately predict the resource types and quantities it will require each week/month, this will cause its orders to fluctuate, creating greater uncertainty in the sales of its suppliers. Effective communication is essential to coordinate efforts and resources within a system, and modularization can assist in preventing changes in one area from disrupting others.
Source: https://lnkd.in/d6trtSAr
#digitaltransformation #digitaltransformationstrategy #businesstransformation #ai #manufacturing #smartfactory #leanmanufacturing #resourcemanagement #decisionmaking #sustainablegrowth ]]>

item.title: Post 219
item.description:
<![CDATA[Companies often assume that if they embrace digital technology in any way, theyâ€™re digitally transforming their business. As a result, they often make only ad hoc changes and investments in the digital arena, with ineffectual results. The challenge, to which most companies have yet to rise, is figuring out how to fully capture the different kinds of value that these technologies offer. Developing a strategy for digital transformation that fully leverages this value is also not easy. Without a comprehensive assessment of what digital technologies can offer, firms tend to assume that any application of modern digital technologies will lead to a digital transformation.
Defined by Harvard Business Review there are four distinct tiers of digital transformation, each of which meets different strategic objectives and allows companies to maximize the value they capture from digital technologies:
1. Tier One: Operational efficiencies 2. Tier Two: Advanced operational efficiencies 3. Tier Three: Data-driven services from value chains 4. Tier Four: Data-driven services from digital platforms
To think properly about these four tiers of transformation, the first step is to recognize that modern digital technologies have two notable value drivers: data in its new expansive role, and emergent digital ecosystems.
Data used to be episodic (generated by discrete events such as the shipment of a component from a supplier), but increasingly it is becoming interactive (generated continuously by sensors and the IoT to track information). Two main kinds of digital ecosystems have emerged, neither of which existed before modern advances in data and digital connectivity. One kind is the production ecosystem, which encompasses digital linkages within value chains. By linking sensor and IoT data from cars to spare-part suppliers, warehouses, and service dealers, for example, car companies can offer predictive maintenance services. The other kind is the consumption ecosystem, which involves networks outside of a firmâ€™s value chain.
#digitaltransformation #businesstransformation #business #innovation #technology #operations]]>

The GII 2022 tracks global innovation trends against the background of an ongoing pandemic, a slowing of productivity growth and other evolving challenges.
The main findings this year are as follows: 1. Contrary to what historic evidence would suggest, science and innovation investments were thriving at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic and boomed in 2021, but their continued resilience is uncertain for 2022 in the face of new challenges. Â Â Â 2. The indicators of technological progress in the fields of semiconductor speeds, electric battery prices, the cost of renewable energy (with the exception of wind) and drug approvals show a significant slowdown from long-term trends and even a decline in the case of drug approvals. Â Â Â 3. Technology adoption is progressing, with positive growth rates across technologies measured by the Global Innovation Tracker, in particular for electric vehicles. However, penetration rates are still medium to low, with the exception of mobile broadband, which reaches the vast majority of the global population. Â Â Â 4. Largely due to the short-term influences of the COVID-19 pandemic, the socioeconomic impact of innovation seems to be at a low point, with labour productivity and life expectancy experiencing a significant slowdown if not coming to a complete standstill, and in the case of carbon dioxide emissions, failing to show ongoing reductions in pollution.

Using Digital Twin technology in retail can help improve inventory management by providing real-time data on stock levels and sales trends, allowing retailers to optimize inventory and reduce waste. Additionally, Digital Twins can simulate store layouts, helping retailers to optimize store design and layout to improve the customer experience, leading to increased sales and customer loyalty.
Digital Twin technology can also be used in supply chain management, allowing retailers to optimize logistics and reduce costs. By simulating supply chain scenarios, retailers can identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies and take steps to address them. This can help retailers to improve their delivery time and customer satisfaction.
However, it's important to note that the implementation of Digital Twin technology should be part of a broader digital transformation strategy. item.title: Post 152
item.description:
<![CDATA[Organisations, until now, have been implementing Industry 4.0 projects with a focus on solving recurring internal challenges or specific issues for the organisation (e.g., better availability, fewer quality defects, visibility of distribution, and right pricing). These solutions have helped them bring in more transparency in their internal systems and savings in their operational costs. However, the next wave of evolution for Industry 4.0 will be to develop solutions that push the boundaries further and help organisations achieve overall optima for their entire value chain.
Driving this new wave of improvements will require a great deal of collaboration between multiple ecosystem partners to come together and develop new integrated solutions. For example, as companies are thinking of reducing the time to market, technologies such as BDA would allow the integration of disparate algorithms, enabling optimisation across the entire value chain, backed by data. The integrated data would help simulate the impact on key parameters using Digital Twins, empowering organisations to take well-informed decisions at the organisation level.
Organisations will have to look beyond the existing internal alliances for Industry 4.0 needs, which includes collaborating with external partners. The outward look would give rise to newer business models with Industry 4.0 at its centre. For this to happen, there is a need for a stronger digital ecosystem with partnerships at business levels. For example, partnerships between big-data analytics (BDA) service providers, Digital Twin solution providers, and connected solutions. Building one architecture to accommodate these aspects would lead to newer business models, and further, manufacturers enriching the data from their own domains.
It is time for the Industry 4.0 ecosystem to collaborate at the business level and meet the growing needs of manufacturers. For this to happen, organisations need to fund newer business models that enable the digital ecosystem.
Source: Deloitte
#business #model #digitaltransformation #industry40 #bigdata #analytics #digitaltwin #businesstransformation]]>

item.title: Post 136

<![CDATA[Digital transformation involves utilizing digital technology to enhance existing services and processes, and companies must continue to look for ways to improve their digital transformation. Organizations that discover innovative methods to serve their consumers, frequently enabled by the deployment of emerging or disruptive technologies, will succeed. AI, cloud-based technology, and blockchain are some of these technologies.
Digital transformation efforts, on the other hand, must instil confidence in digital products and services through alignment with digital trust. When trust is established in digital products and services, customer satisfaction and involvement rise, leading to greater business outcomes and growth for an organisation.
As a result, a digital trust mindset should underpin how organizations approach digital transformation. Leaders may play a significant role in aiding the digital trust journey within their businesses by determining if any transformation activities that are now ongoing or are about to begin have adequately integrated trust considerations from the start. Leaders can look out for their various stakeholders and ensure that trust is going alongside the bottom line.

item.title: Post 131
item.description:
<![CDATA[What is Business Process Management and how it helps digital transformation?
Technologies that challenge the status quo are those that enable digital transformation. Digital transformation is a process of using technology to create new or improved business processes, products, or services. This can be done in order to reduce costs, improve efficiency, or create new revenue streams.
Digital transformation can be enabled by a number of different technologies, including cloud computing, artificial intelligence, big data, and the Internet of Things. These technologies can challenge the status quo by making it possible to do things that were previously not possible, or by making existing processes more efficient.
The benefits of digital transformation can be significant. For example, Accenture estimates that digital transformation can help companies achieve a 30 percent reduction in costs. McKinsey has found that companies that have embraced digital transformation are 26 percent more profitable than their peers.
However, digital transformation can also be disruptive. It can challenge existing business models and lead to the need for new skills and processes. As such, it is important for companies to carefully consider how they can best take advantage of digital transformation while minimizing its risks.
Innovation and constant breakthroughs in the worlds of business and IT mean that the status quo of running a business is constantly shifting. BPM (Business Process Management) itself has shifted from a one-time initiative to a constant process.
Follow me for daily insights on digital transformation. Hit the bell icon ğŸ””on my profile.
#bpm #businessprocess #businesstransformation #digitaltransformation #rpa #innovation #process #optimisation]]>

<![CDATA[Where Web1 focused on static pages, and Web2 thrived on user-generated content, Web3 is about assigning value to that content.
One of the advantages of Web2 was the ability to share digital assets at a low cost. But the information was easy to share because it was easy to copy. As a result, enterprise marketers didnâ€™t invest much attention or money in creating high-value digital assets.
Web3 changes this by making it possible to assign to a digital asset a non-fungible token, which is a digital identifier that canâ€™t be copied or changed. The NFT is then recorded in a blockchain, or a digital ledger in which records (called blocks) are linked using cryptography.

The term â€œmachine as a serviceâ€ (MaaS) is used to describe the outsourcing of the management and maintenance of machinery to a specialist service provider. The service provider is responsible for ensuring that the machinery is kept in good working order and is available to the customer on an as-needed basis.
MaaS arrangements are becoming increasingly popular as businesses seek to reduce their costs and free up their own staff to focus on their core activities. There are a number of advantages to using a MaaS provider, including access to expertise and specialist equipment, lower costs, and increased flexibility. First, it can be cheaper than buying a machine outright, since you're only paying for the use of the machine, not the entire purchase price. Second, it can be more convenient, since the company takes care of maintenance and repairs.
MaaS providers typically offer a range of services, from simple repair and maintenance services to more comprehensive support packages that include regular servicing, 24/7 support, and emergency call-out services. When choosing a MaaS provider, it is important to consider their experience, reputation, and the range of services they offer. You should also make sure that you are clear about the terms of the agreement, including any charges for call-outs or other services.
So if you're in the market for a new machine, but don't want the hassle of owning one, consider a machine as a service. It just might be the perfect solution for you.

item.title: Post 106
item.description:
<![CDATA[Companies often assume that if they embrace digital technology in any way, theyâ€™re digitally transforming their business. As a result, they often make only ad hoc changes and investments in the digital arena, with ineffectual results. The challenge, to which most companies have yet to rise, is figuring out how to fully capture the different kinds of value that these technologies offer. Developing a strategy for digital transformation that fully leverages this value is also not easy. Without a comprehensive assessment of what digital technologies can offer, firms tend to assume that any application of modern digital technologies will lead to a digital transformation.
Defined by Harvard Business Review there are four distinct tiers of digital transformation, each of which meets different strategic objectives and allows companies to maximize the value they capture from digital technologies:
1. Tier One: Operational efficiencies 2. Tier Two: Advanced operational efficiencies 3. Tier Three: Data-driven services from value chains 4. Tier Four: Data-driven services from digital platforms
To think properly about these four tiers of transformation, the first step is to recognize that modern digital technologies have two notable value drivers: data in its new expansive role, and emergent digital ecosystems.
Data used to be episodic (generated by discrete events such as the shipment of a component from a supplier), but increasingly it is becoming interactive (generated continuously by sensors and the IoT to track information). Two main kinds of digital ecosystems have emerged, neither of which existed before modern advances in data and digital connectivity. One kind is the production ecosystem, which encompasses digital linkages within value chains. By linking sensor and IoT data from cars to spare-part suppliers, warehouses, and service dealers, for example, car companies can offer predictive maintenance services. The other kind is the consumption ecosystem, which involves networks outside of a firmâ€™s value chain.
#digitaltransformation #businesstransformation #business #innovation]]>

item.title: Post 98
item.description:
<![CDATA[High uncertainty and low growth have already forced manufacturers to squeeze every asset for maximum value. The next target is their own data.
Applying advanced analytics to manufacturersâ€™ data can produce insights to optimize the productivity of individual assets as well as the total manufacturing operation. Deployed in conjunction with each other, these tools enable operators to maximize their productivity and profitability.
Predictive maintenance analyses the historical performance data of machines to forecast when one is likely to fail, limit the time it is out of service, and identify the root cause of the problem. Yield-energy-throughput (YET) analytics can be used to ensure that those individual machines are as efficient as possible when they are operating, helping to increase their yields and throughput and reduce the amount of energy they consume. Profit-per-hour (PPH) maximization analytics, meanwhile, scrutinizes the thousands of parameters and conditions that have an impact on the total profitability of an integrated supply chain (from raw materials purchasing to final sales), providing intelligence on how best to capitalize on given conditions.
Together, these advanced analytics approaches can deliver EBITDA margin improvements of as much as 4 to 10 percent.]]>

With so much at stake to build digital capabilities that drive customer centricity and productivity, why do so many companies fail? Successful transformations also set companies up for sustained success; they wonâ€™t have to digitally transform again as they master continuous innovation. Investors say that 50% of companies should invest more aggressively in digital capabilities and technology.
But there is a conundrum for management: digital transformations are difficult to execute. And with so much on the line, only 30% of transformations succeed in achieving their objectives. Organizational inertia from deeply rooted behaviours is a big impediment.
Failure should not be an option, and yet it is the most common result. The consequences in terms of investments of money, organizational effort, and elapsed time are massive. Digital laggards fall behind in customer engagement, process efficiency, and innovation.
When trying to bring everyone along with the overall plan, it can be easy to compromise and lose focus on the transformational aspiration. This is where the trouble usually starts. Itâ€™s easy to see why more and more manufacturing companies are talking about whatâ€™s often called the circular economyâ€”in which businesses create supply chains that recover or recycle the resources used to create their products. Shrinking their environmental footprint, trimming operational waste, and using expensive resources more efficiently are certainly appealing to CEOs.
But creating a circular business model is challenging, and taking the wrong approach can be expensive. 1ï¸âƒ£Retain product ownership (RPO) - the producer rents or leases its product to the customer rather than selling it. Thus the producer is responsible for products when consumers have finished with them.
2ï¸âƒ£Product life extension (PLE). Companies applying this strategy focus on designing products to last longer, which may open up possibilities for markets in used products. item.title: Post 70
item.description:
<![CDATA[Industry 4.0 has transformed the way new products are designed and engineered. The use of sensors, wearables, analytics, and Machine Learning (ML), as well as advanced manufacturing, Augmented Reality/Virtual Reality (AR/VR), advanced computer numerical control, and robotics have improved products in multiple ways. Industries have moved from rapid prototyping and testing to adding connectivity features to unconnected products along with innovative features.
Organisations are now moving towards monetising the data that they capture via smart products and bundle services in addition to physical assets. Digital signals from consumer interactions with connected assets on the field or from the assets themselves can enable better services and improve warranty claims, visibility into usage patterns, and overall revenue streams.
To utilise these opportunities arising from Industry 4.0, it is necessary to shift from traditional to novel business models.
Smart products present a spectrum of new business model innovations to capture value. For example, there has been a recent shift from traditional ownership models (where customer benefits from the product delivered) to a Product-as-a-Service model (PaaS), where the manufacturer retains ownership and takes full responsibility for the costs of product operation, maintenance, and service in return for a fixed fee. This enables customers to pay as they go. Here, the value from the improvement in product performance, reduction in the overall cost of production, and higher service efficiency are captured by the manufacturer.
Source: Deloitte

<![CDATA[How would you define a digital twin?
Many companies define a â€œdigital twinâ€ as a virtual representation of a process. But for a digital twin to achieve its mission for better optimization, predictive planning, and operational efficiencies, a digital twin must be:
- Truly real-time â€” with streams of data constantly optimizing and reoptimizing the model.
- AI-enabled, and enabling AI â€” managed, refined, and optimized by AI models, and used to train AI perception models in autonomous machines or vehicles.
- Physically accurate â€” full-fidelity 3D representation of the process, system or environment.
- Synchronized to a single physical twin â€” a digital twin is a twin of only one singular model, and must be in a real-time, constant feedback loop with its one physical twin.

item.title: Post 60

<![CDATA[How to build a data-driven company?
Creating a data culture is one of the keys to building a data-driven organization. The right technology, data literacy, and disrupting the status quo are ways to start.
Data is no longer just a by-product of transactional systems. Applications and technology are now designed around what data is needed for a business to make decisions.
Companies should organize their systems and applications to give the right people access to data so they can make decisions quickly, instead of having data â€œdumped somewhere and then massaged and arranged for better analytics to make a decision a week or a month or a year later.â€
While the right technology is not an easy shortcut to a data culture, technology and culture are two sides of the same coin as both depend on being open to new ways of doing things. Companies with outdated technology â€” reports and dashboards, on-premises enterprise data warehouses, siloed data marts, and email as the primary source of communication â€” often have a culture where data is hoarded.
Instead, companies should invest in a modern technology portfolio with AI-driven insights, data lakes, collaboration tools like Slack, cloud-based, logical data warehouses, and augmented analytics. This often correlates to an innovative culture where data is democratized, there is transparency and trust, expertise and insights are shared, and people feel empowered and energized to embrace the new.
Great article on how to build a data-driven company: http://ow.ly/eWIG50JrQ43.

<![CDATA[The seven golden principles for getting the best out of Industry 4.0
The digitally enabled factory of today looks very different from the leading factory of ten years ago. Advances in data and analytics, AI, and MLâ€”and the array of technology vendors in the marketâ€”mean manufacturers can choose from hundreds of potential solutions and tech applications to improve their ways of working.
Implemented successfully, these solutions deliver irresistible returns. Across a wide range of sectors, it is not uncommon to see 30 to 50 percent reductions in machine downtime, 10 to 30 percent increases in throughput, 15 to 30 percent improvements in labour productivity, and 85 percent more accurate forecasting.
Digital transformations are revolutionizing all aspects of manufacturing, touching not just processes and productivity but also people. The right applications of technology can lead to more empowered decision making; new opportunities for upskilling, reskilling, and cross-functional collaboration; better talent attraction and retention; and improved workplace safety and employee satisfaction.
Customers see the impacts through reduced manufacturing lead times, right-first-time launch management, and improved customer service and complexity management. And, of course, there are the winâ€“win advantages associated with reduced environmental impact, made possible through lower emissions and reduced waste and more efficient energy, water, and raw-material consumption.
Whether manufacturers are starting out on their digital-transformation journeysâ€”or recalibrating their approach after false starts or failed attemptsâ€”the approaches adopted by leading companies point to seven golden principles for scaling a successful digital transformation: 1. Communicate well and often 2. Be specific 3. Segment, select, and syndicate 4. Formalize the value at stake 5. Develop a three- to five-year vision for the network 6. Design a digital-manufacturing road map 7. Syndicate the vision and secure leadership buy-in]]>

item.title: Post 53
item.description:
<![CDATA[Organisations, until now, have been implementing Industry 4.0 projects with a focus on solving recurring internal challenges or specific issues for the organisation (for e.g., better availability, fewer quality defects, visibility of distribution, right pricing). These solutions have helped them bring in more transparency in their internal systems and savings in their operational costs. However, the next wave of evolution for Industry 4.0 will be to develop solutions that push the boundaries further and help organisations achieve overall optima for their entire value chain.
Driving this new wave of improvements will require a great deal of collaboration between multiple ecosystem partners to come together and develop new integrated solutions. For example, as companies are thinking of reducing the time to market, technologies such BDA would allow integration of disparate algorithms, enabling optimisation across the entire value chain, backed by data. The integrated data would help simulate the impact on key parameters using Digital Twins, empowering organisations to take well-informed decisions at the organisation level.
Organisations will have to look beyond the existing internal alliances for Industry 4.0 needs, which includes collaborating with external partners. The outward look would give rise to newer business models with Industry 4.0 at its centre. For this to happen, there is a need for a stronger digital ecosystem with partnerships at business levels. For example, partnerships between big-data analytics (BDA) service providers, Digital Twin solution providers, and connected solutions. Building one architecture to accommodate these aspects would lead to newer business models, and further, manufacturers enriching the data from their own domains.
It is time for the Industry 4.0 ecosystem to collaborate at the business level and meet the growing needs of manufacturers. For this to happen, organisations need to fund newer business models that enable the digital ecosystem.
Source: Deloitte

When I speak to clients about their business challenges, they often mention slow processes, untimely data and a lack of functional optimization that leads to potential losses in revenue. While there are multiple ways of solving these problems, the use of â€œdigital twinsâ€ is gaining traction.
From an operations perspective, digital twins do three things: 1. Mirror the exact appearance of the main object 2. Behave in an identical fashion 3. Process and analyze information
But the accuracy of models relies on three elementsâ€“quality and quantity of data, enabling technologies and business applications such as enterprise resource planning (ERP). Setting the right operations foundations in place is vital for using digital twins to their full advantage and enhancing business performance. Data has multiple sourcesâ€“whether internal or external. Like any other intelligent system, high-quality data is the lifeblood of the twin models of the process flows. Data-led insights can act as a precursor for solving multiple what-if conditions, including the identification of process deviations. item.title: Post 21
item.description:
<![CDATA[â“How to coordinate multiple pathways to digital transformation?
Digital transformation can be described as business transformation using digital capabilities. In other words, itâ€™s more than just adopting technology for technologyâ€™s sake. There are four common paths to digital transformation. For some companies, it makes sense to choose more than one.
ğŸ¯ The researchers found that transformation must happen in two ways: better customer experience and improved operational efficiency. Firms can make progress on one, both, or neither, and they typically take four different pathways to transformation:
1. focus on transforming operations, which commonly means building new business services enabled by application programming interfaces (APIs).
2. focus on an integrated customer experience if metrics such as net promoter score fall well below the industry average
3. take incremental steps in each direction over several iterations, starting with a small step to improve the customer experience (such as a new mobile app) and following that with a small step to streamline operations (such as a new customer relationship management system).
4. starting fresh with a spinoff company â€” an option if leaders of the current company donâ€™t think itâ€™s possible to change culture, customer experience, and operations fast enough to survive.
Pathways suited to one business unit might not work for another, and sometimes it makes sense to pursue multiple pathways. One part of the business may need an immediate improvement to customer service, while another may have more latitude to take incremental steps.
http://ow.ly/1m9Q50JBnOS ]]>

According to Accenture, data-driven companies are propelled by four key drivers. They:
1) Establish a solid data foundation: Achieved through an agile data supply chain with cloud-based and scalable platforms.
2) Ensure data is secure, relevant and trustworthy: Accomplished through robust data governance, metadata management and data veracity solutions. This is enabled by machine learning (ML) or artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, right people structures and processes. Only a third of firms trusted their data enough to use it effectively and derive value from it.
3) Create an analytics strategy: Attained by focusing on augmenting human efforts with AI and by building capabilities in advanced analytics. Almost 90 per cent of data-driven champions in the survey could attest to being highly involved in data analytics processes and automated approaches as opposed to 54 per cent of others.
4) Envision and launch new data-driven services: Realized through innovative business models and operational efficiency measures. Using a data value scorecard, business outcomes can be measured, tracked and reported effectively.
